I am so grateful to be alive today. My girlfriend saved my life last night. This is a selfie I took in the emergency room after having a severe allergic reaction to almonds. I went into anaphylaxis, meaning my face, my lips, my eyes, my tongue, and my throat all started swelling up rapidly, making it almost impossible for me to breathe. I also had a rash all over my entire body, and I was extremely red. Staying alive had never felt more difficult. At one point, my nasal passage was completely blocked, and it was getting more and more difficult to breathe. They shot me up with Benadryl, steroids, they gave me a breathing tube, and even other stuff that I can’t even remember, and it caused all of the swelling and the rash to go away. Because this was a severe allergic reaction, I need to continue taking steroids and Benadryl for the next week, because it is possible that the allergic reactions could come back at any point over the next week. The steroids and Benadryl make me feel like a zombie, and I really want to take care of my health, so this will be my main focus over the next week. I want to thank my amazing girlfriend, who made the decision to take me to the emergency room the second I started feeling itchy. I was hesitant about going, because I didn’t even want to believe this was actually happening. If it weren’t for my girlfriend driving me to the emergency room only minutes after eating the almonds, there is a good chance that I wouldn’t have made it according to the doctor. This has been without a doubt the hardest few days of my life, but I also look at them as the most important few days of my life. These moments have reminded me about what’s really important in life, and it has made me so grateful to even be here on this earth. I will be prioritizing my health over the next week, and I’ll post updates about how I feel. Thank you all for being patient during these difficult times. This week has been NUTS (too soon for jokes? 😅)

In such cases, it probably makes sense to talk about impedance because some of the energy is stored in the reactive element - the elastic surface of the ball - as deformation. Thus, acceleration is influenced not only by the energy that you transfer to the ball, but also by how you transfer it - through which contact patch. If we make a special cup, which would push the ball more evenly over the surface, then the kinetic energy of the platform will be converted more quickly into the kinetic energy of the ball, to a greater extent avoiding the stage of accumulation. In other words, there will be an improvement in the impedance matching of the power source and the receiver.

Around 8:56 - 9:03 you mention a "rebound as the bat goes backwards and ignites the cartridges" and a "little bity lag time" noticed while waiting on the cartridges to light off. I think this could be related to firearm "lock time". If you could change the charges to electronic primed cartridges like Remington EtronX, this rebound and lag time could be greatly reduced if not eliminated. I think lowering this time would increase the efficiency in the energy transfer from bat to ball, especially as you increase the bat speed. In the collaboration with Stuff Made Here, this loss of efficiency isn't a big deal since he was always swinging rather slow so the ball was still "relatively" close to the bat when the cartridges ignited. However, as bat speed increases, this initial bounce could move the ball further and further away from the bat reducing the effectiveness/efficiency of the piston mechanism. Just an idea to consider if you merge this concept with Mad Batter.

Or would that somewhat negate things?

Great video and I have a Video Idea!  Can you do a video about failure and how engineers decide something is good enough?  I feel like it would be really relevant to educators today teaching engineering in schools or parents at home.  As a fellow engineer, I find there is a point for all engineers when we realize perfectionism is just unrealistic.  Success is what you define it to be.  I taught 3rd grade science/engineering for a year in grad school and quickly learned that the fear of failure or looking inadequate is powerful.  The fear of failure is probably the main reason there is a shortage of engineers/scientists.  People need permission to have their plans not work and always an opportunity to try again.   Often educators get the trying part but don't allot enough time in their schedules to give their students the opportunity to try again.  Iterative problem solving is the core of the engineering design process.  The motto of the US Army Corps of Engineers is "Essayons" and means "let us try."

if you paus at: 10:09 you can see the velocity over time diagramm for 3 charges.
There you can see the drop of the paddle at 3.5s.
Then you can calculate the deceleration of the paddle:
The paddle drops from over 150mph to almost Zero in half a millisecond.
That gives you a velocity differenz of: 150mph = 240 km/h = 66 m/s.
so to get the acceleration or in that case the deceleration you divide it by the time of 1/2 millisecond: (66 m/s) / 1/2000s = 132 000 m/s^2.
To get the g number just divide it by Erthacceleration: 132 000 / 9.81 = 13 455g.
SO THE PADDEL DECELERATE WITH OVER 13 Thousand g!!!!!

Days and Nights aren’t even “things”. They are an expression of how the earth turns on its axis. That’s all. But people 2000 years ago didn’t know this. That’s why it is described that way in the bible. If god wanted to go for accuracy, why didn’t he explain that the sun was actually a star? Why didn’t he explain the earth and the planets and how the revolution of the earth is what determined night and day?

We get nothing from God. Nothing from the Bible, that explains anything more than what they already thought to be true 2000 years ago.

If there actually was a God, imagine the things he could have told us about the world around us. About gravity, and germs, and things smaller than the eye can see, about the reason for earthquakes, volcanos and hurricanes. But he didn’t. Because he doesn’t exist.

And before you start saying that the Bible wasn’t “about” these types of things - that it’s more of an Instruction on morality and how to live - God couldn’t even set the precedent that slavery was wrong. Even Jesus said, “slaves obey your masters”. So the Bible is not a reliable source of morality, either. Because it was written by men. The same men who created this God in their image. Because that was their way of making sense of the world back then.

We’ve moved on. We no longer believe that a god or gods are responsible for night and day. We no longer believe in a ridiculous boat carrying all the world’s species during a great flood. We no longer believe that a man can survive in the belly of a whale. We no longer believe that it’s a good idea to sacrifice one person for the misdeeds of another.

God only exists as an abstract concept within our gaps of knowledge, blinking out of existence every time one of those gaps are filled.

Nononono! The reason you didn't see a big increase in velocity on the 4-charge shot was because the length of the "power stroke" is limited (and that's also why the "blowout"). There wasn't enough range of movement in the device to allow for maximum power to be applied to the ball. This is why a longer draw length on a bow results in a faster arrow.

The power generated by the .22 charges needs somewhere to go. You tried to correct it by basically not making the piston system on the bat a "captured" system, but once the pistons released from the frame of the bat, the power generated was free to move away from centerline. Not efficient. It would be more efficient if the pistons could be made longer to maximize the power stroke on the ball...but in a specific, controlled direction. Not an engineer, just my observation. Lengthen and capture the piston stroke = more power applied to the ball=longer home run.

This is nothing more than two homework problems in a mechanical or aerospace engineering class.  You're going to need a little baseball aerodynamics to determine the initial force required for a ball to travel 1,000 feet.  You have acceleration from the bat and deceleration (or negative acceleration) due to drag (which is proportional to the decreasing velocity squared).  As for creating the initial force, it's a spring-mass-damper system.  Do some reading and figure out if 1,000 feet is possible given the driving force from the bat against the springy damped mass.  You can determine the coefficients you need by matching the differential equations to the slopes on graphs you made from the slo-mo.  Get to work.  You have to turn this in tomorrow.

I see three hurdles you need to overcome.

1) consistent contact
2) consistent launch angle
3) backspin

For consistent contact, you need to make the plate flat, not curved, and you need it at least 30% higher than the ball diameter

For consistent loft, you need to habe that plate at an angle so you only need to make a level swing

For back spin you need to have some sort of groove with edges at an angle to bite on to the ball.

I am far from an engineer and being dyslexic, I don't do well with large formulas so the launch angle and spin are things that you would have to test out and those would be dictated by speed. With a golf driver, a ball speed of 200 mph a good launch angle and spin combo is about 10 deg and 2000 rpm for the best distance. This will be different for a baseball based on seams verses threads, but probably in the ballpark (intended😉)

I would guess that you could easily hit over 800' by improving launch and spin conditions.

Also, paint your ball so it is easier to find.

Hey hey people, there's still at least 2x momentum lying on the floor I believe. As you said, "the impedance" or the combination of the laws of conservation of moment and energy is important. When a billiard ball hits another billiard ball, it simply transfers its momentum to it. If a much heavier billiard ball hits another billiard ball, the lighter ball flies away at almost twice the velocity (same thing fundamentally as a gravity assist under perfect conditions). So my suggestion is to use a much heavier hitter plate and correspondingly more charge, because what you are using seems to be about the same weight as the baseball.

Here for the algorithm.

We can observe that an enormous amount of gas is still being released after the piston/projectile has reached the end of its travel.

Or, put another way: it would be fully burned (releasing all of its energy) by the time the pistons (initial projectile) reach their end of travel. Sure, it's impressive to see the exhausting flame and gases, but from a standpoint of physics (and internal ballistics in particular) it represents wasted energy. Ideally, every bit of the chemical energy would be imparted to the initial projectile (pistons) at the moment they're fully extended.

Alas, there may not be powder-actuated charges readily available with a greater burn rate. However, a bit of exploration and engineering with someone competent in internal ballistics and everything will become clear... or, rather, much more distant.

I thought the acceleration of the striker piece was really impressive so I decide to do the acceleration calculations.
1 charge:
accelerated from approx 25 mph to 100 mph
Time: approx .5 millisecond
acceleration in m/s^2 = 67,056 m/s^2
2 charges:
accelerated from approx 25 mph to 133 mph
Time: approx 2.66 milliseconds
acceleration in m/s^2 = 18,150.496 m/s^2
3 charges:
accelerated from approx 40 mph to 150 mph (Destin's charge 3 graph has it go over 150 but in charge 4 graph its under 150 so im using charge 3 graph data)
time approx 2 milliseconds
acceleration in m/s^2 = 24,587.2 m/s^2
4 charges:
accelerated from approx 25 mph to 125 mph
time approx 2 milli seconds
accleration in ms/^2 = 22,352 m/s^2

Which is really impressive given the size and mass of the baseball (142-149 grams according to wiki)

Destin, the 4 cartridge swing was different for more reasons than you talk about (but I'm actually not sure how significant those reasons are). Firstly, there wasn't a human with mass swinging the bat on the 4 cartridge swings.  So for the first three swing tests, you didn't just have a bat and a ball colliding, you had a bat-human system and a ball colliding.  The rotation angle was also different for the 4th swing.  On the 4th swing, the pivot point for the "arm" of the bat  "lever" was on the handle.  In the first 3 swings that pivot point is closer to the human.  Maybe not center-line down the human but definitely not at the handle.
